events.body:
> checking whether byte ordering is bigendian... yes

\o/

It worked on core :P
But still satisfying to see.
There's nothing more satisfying than seeing that your code works on an edge case you never tested before lol
Cool! What's missing for un-WIP'ing? How about turning on the ECDH and recovery module?

issue.title: General CI discussion
issue.body:
When thinking about #705 I realized it's maybe a good idea to take a step back and look at this in the context of a general CI revamp. There are multiple things that would be nice and I think some of these probably have a higher priority than coverage reports:

 - ARM tests https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/598
 - Big-endian tests https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/696
 - Windows and/or MSVC builds? (https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/issues/451#issuecomment-746752833)
 - MacOS builds? (MacOS relies on clang anyway, so not this is not as interesting as MSVC.)
 - Coverage reports #705 
 - Reducing configuration options to keep the test matrix manageable, see e.g., https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/596#issuecomment-495908309

Is there anything else you would like to see?

If we want to work on this, this is a good time to think about the CI platform. I don't mind Travis and it's reasonably stable in the past months but if we think that a different (or additional) provider is a better fit, it's better to discuss this before we start working on these issues.

By the way, Bitcoin is currently looking into GitHub Actions for Windows at least:
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/17803

issue.title: Get rid of autoconf check for endianness
issue.body:
This does not fix any particular issue but it's preferable to not
rely on autoconf. This avoids endianness mess for users on BE hosts
if they use their build without autoconf.

events.body:
> Cool! What's missing for un-WIP'ing? How about turning on the ECDH and recovery module?

@sipa Could you do this, and maybe also add a comment to the Travis file that this is a big-endian host?

issue.title: Travis should build and test arm asm

rename.from: [WIP] Let's see if s390x testing works
rename.to: Run a Travis test on s390x (big endian)

events.body:
Rebased, and added ECDH/recovery.

I did notice valgrind ctime test failure on this line in src/scalar_4x64_impl.h:

```c
    no |= (a->d[1] < SECP256K1_N_1);
```

so I've disabled the ctime test for now.

> ```c
>     no |= (a->d[1] < SECP256K1_N_1);
> ```

and two lines below too:

https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/master/src/scalar_4x64_impl.h#L65

> 
> so I've disabled the ctime test for now.

makes sense.

ACK c5e43bb8d6c60c5f8ee38c89ac4d0d755e6515d0 Travis works and says it's big endian

The travis failure is a randomness test again (#68), see https://travis-ci.org/github/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/jobs/713125311#L497 

If you want, you can squash this. Otherwise I'll just merge it in the next days if noone objects.

issue.title: Check if variable=yes instead of if var is set in travis.sh
issue.body:
Right now travis.sh checks if  `VALGRIND` and `CTIMETEST` are set or not, but in travis.yml we explictly set them to `yes` so I think it's more intuitive to check if they're equal to `yes` such that setting `CTIMETEST=no`(or anything other than "yes") will disable the test. 

pointed out by @real-or-random here: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/696#discussion_r462053453

events.body:
ACK 39295362cfc856aae1c37cc1194c2f6d53fd6f25 Travis works and says it's big endian

(I squashed this for merging).

issue.title: Use preprocessor macros instead of autoconf to detect endianness
issue.body:
This does not fix any particular issue but it's preferable to not
rely on autoconf. This avoids endianness mess for users on BE hosts
if they use their build without autoconf.

The macros are carefully written to err on the side of the caution,
e.g., we #error if the user manually configures a different endianness
than what we detect.

Supersedes #770 .
